Update: Made it to the pharmacy, with the help of a friend. 

I couldn't actually make myself take a bus or lyft/uber. 

Agoraphobia sucks.

And yes, I'd give anything not to feel this way. To be able to just go. 

I've been sitting here over an hour, just trying to be *comfortable* enough to leave. 

I hate it.

While I 'look healthy' I'm a T1 Diabetic with physical limitations and I have agoraphobia. 

Really freaking bad. 
I have worked very hard to be comfortable going anywhere. The pharmacy is one of them, out of necessity, but it is *Hard* to go anywhere alone.

I'm so tired.

Still don't have an insulin pump, new glasses, or therapist.

I should be farther along than this. The people who promised to help me with rides, didn't help. I eventually got angry/hurt enough to complain.

I'm back to taking buses to get to appointments.

The nightmares about these specific events are rare, but are more common when I have other stresses.

This is the first time I've had nightmares about this in almost a year? Six months at least. I have other nightmares, reoccurring ones, but most of them aren't about real events.

I'm still shaking. I cried writing this.

I shouldn't feel guilty, but I do. Survivor's Guilt. Knowing what it is doesn't help.

I'm ashamed that I escaped. 

I was 13, now I'm 42. Abuse has lasting consequences. 

But I can still love people and help them.

That's enough for me.

cw/ CSA

It took years of therapy, soul searching, and loving support from good people to heal. I'm still working on it. Those scars still hurt.  

Talk to your children about consent, about personal boundaries, about how to be safe. I know it's difficult, but it is so important.

Angel was convicted. She went to jail.

Still, I told no one. For a long time, I blamed myself, hated myself, and pursued my own destruction. I began to distrust anyone who liked me, because surely I had fooled them. 

I was a monster. 

It took decades to heal from those wounds.

cw/ suicidal ideation, mental health, addiction

My memories came back, with no mercy. I blamed myself, because I never told anyone. Because I didn't stop her.

I hated myself.

I seriously considered not existing. I spent as much time as possible drunk or stoned.

I told no one.

That was the first, but not the last time, someone I knew was murdered. I consoled my friend, went home, and tried not to think about it. 

A week or two later? The news reported they had suspects in custody. 

Angel's face stared back at me from a mugshot. 

I fell apart.

Even then, I told no one. Not even my friends. 

A couple years passed. I wasn't 18 yet. I mostly forgot her, but I have CPTSD and DID, forgetting things was a defense mechanism. 

Then, someone I knew was murdered. Not a close friend, but family to a friend. Someone I knew.

It lasted only a couple months, but it was abusive manipulation for 'affection'. I was obsessed, did anything she said, and actively hid it from everyone.

I thought she loved me, I was afraid to lose her.

She ghosted me, her phone number changed. She moved.

I blamed myself.

She was shocked at my age, but that didn't stop her from flirting with me. It just got worse. 

What followed was a guided manipulation. She didn't push; she didn't have to. Socialized as a 'male teen' I thought sleeping with an older woman was 'cool'.

I was a perfect victim.

I've never talked about this publicly and I'm scared to. Even though I'm 42 and she can't hurt me anymore.

I met 'Angel' online. We played video games together, meeting through mutual friends. She was flirty, I responded. Mutual friends invited me to a meet-up.

Angel was there.

CW grooming, abuse, SA, murder

I've been shaking since I woke up. I had vicious nightmares last night. The type that twist your worst moments into something even more horrible.

I was groomed as a teenager. When I was, 13? I'm not sure. My childhood is a blur of lost memories.

This is still happening, but I've been sicccck. xDD

I've always been interested in VR, augmented reality, and virtual worlds. 

The direct brain interface devices interest me, but I doubt I'll see anything like cyberpunk fiction in my lifetime. 

Which makes me sad, but I *can* be alone in a group.

Why I want to, I don't know.

More recently, I've wandered around in VR chat, without the VR, ofc. (I'm poor)

That has been interesting and weird. Random people talking, interacting. Small groups forming and discussing things.
It gives that feeling of being alone in a group. Not the same, but almost there.

Getting invested in an RP group wasn't possible as a parent with a full time job anyway.

Instead, I ended up sitting in taverns on RP servers like Moonguard and occasionally had interesting conversations with random people while ERPers frolicked around us.

It was unsatisfying.

As a long time TTRPGer, I used to play 2-3 times a week. When I discovered MMORPGs, I was intrigued in the Roleplay aspect. 

What I found wasn't quite for me. 

I didn't want to take part in large stories or campaigns, I wanted the improv aspect, the personal interaction.

CW/ Pandemic talk, 

Since lockdown, I've hit a couple points where I've missed bars. Not for alcohol, but for people. Specifically that feeling of being in public, but alone. 

Existing and being alone, but not being alone. 

Nothing quite replaces it. But MMORPGs come close.

Though I would get hit on, bars have bouncers, and any regular will tell you that making friends with your bouncer is essential. 

Most of my barfly existence was in my 20s

When I wanted to lose myself, I went to clubs and danced. 
When I wanted quiet, I found a corner and hid.

Not being with people and interacting, really. Being surrounded by people and being alone. 

Being alone in a group. 

I have pretty severe agoraphobia, but bars often felt safe. Most often, I was dressed as an angry punk in a leather and a lot of spikes, so I got left alone.

cw/ alcohol, alcoholism, depression

So, I am an alcoholic. I rarely break and have a drink, but I'm still an alcoholic.   

I've gotten to the point I don't really miss drinking, but sometimes I miss bars. 

If found when I get lonely for bars, I'm really lonely for people.

cw/ mental health, abuse

Depression has cycles.

I have CPTSD, DID, anxiety. I survived abuse and trauma.

Things that will always hurt.

I've spent years in therapy.

The thing that's helped most is learning to forgive myself for not being strong.

For not always being perfect.

cw/ mental health

It's hard, because depression will twist your thoughts. Make you believe your best moments are selfish.

Reject the lies; Try to see clearly.

If you truly need to work on you, then commit to changing.

It's hard. It's brutal and cruel.

but it's also freeing.

cw/ mental health

Especially because you don't want to. That depression pulls you down, replays your worst moments, your worst choices, your worst memories.

Depression LIES.

It omits all the good memories, your selfless deeds. 

So you fight back with that, with your decency.

Mind you, I'm a very positive person. I'm sarcastic, a bit jaded, but...

I chose to be positive.

Depression is cruel, it worms it's way in. Before you realize it, negative thoughts try to crush you. 

The most effective defense? reject it, fight back, even if you don't want to.

Ugh... blood sugar was 63 when I checked it. (I have eaten since)

Of course, my body feels like crap and I'm fatigued af, but I can't sleep. I have to make sure my blood sugar stablizes. 

I am being very careful, which makes this extra frustrating.
n0ice

Insulin pumps provide more precise insulin delivery than vials or pens. 

Better insulin management reduces hypo/hyperglycemia, symptoms and slows the damage that uncontrolled diabetes does to the body. 

DKA being just one example of deadly side effects.

That being said, my fears are more about what DKA does to me, because it is hard on the body. I worry someday I won't survive it, or I will be weakened due to it, and succumb to another, normally less deadly illness. 

Getting an insulin pump decreases that possibility.

DKA is the most painful thing I have ever experienced. Even the memory of DKA pain scares me.

I would normally say I have a high pain threshold. It doesn't matter; I'm powerless against this. 

When I was hospitalized the last time, they gave me Fentanyl for DKA. 

Fentanyl.

While it can hit very rapidly and very strong, I have been lucky. My acidity is moderate, my blood sugar has been volatile, but manageable. 

the nausea and fatigue have been challenging, especially when it comes to making sure I eat, but by far the pain is the most difficult.

Sorry, this is all very TW // Medical, Mortality. 

DKA can be triggered by factors like: illness, missed insulin shots, infection.

I have been hospitalized for DKA 4 times. Each of those times related to another illness. A minor cold or my dental issues, triggered DKA.

For those unfamiliar with why I freaked out... let me explain Diabetic Ketoacidosis a bit.

If your body doesn't have enough insulin to process glucose for energy, it burns fat for energy instead. This process produces keytones, which are acidic.

Too much acidity and you die.

Where are we at? I managed to eat solid food yesterday, but it tired me out and I slept most of the day.

I am still sick, but my keytones are down and my glucose numbers are better. 

I have received a over $1000 in donations. 

The support is humbling. Thank you so very much! https://t.co/jGlEwSwpBH

I almost never talk about this stuff. It isn't new or special. This is JUST A DAY.
People need help; I do what I can. I advise new diabetics about their illness. I secure gender affirming gear for trans teens. I sit up all night with a friend in need.

It's the right thing to do.

When the emergency passed and my loved one needed someone to be there for her, I was waiting. 

Because it's what you do. It's the right thing to do.

We talked about what happened.

And I told her how damned proud I am of her. (and I am)

I talked with her until she could sleep.

She went and did the hard thing. She helped her friend, got them professional help, managed multiple complications that no one should have to deal with. 

She did the damn thing and helped someone. 

Because it's what you do in an emergency. It's the right thing to do.

Once the decision was made, and really what else were we going to do?we both sprang into action.
I gave her the best advice I could: Listen, acknowledge the pain, be there for them NOW, and help them get to professional help.

That's what most of us need, someone to be there.

I sat there in that moment, with my loved one, where you know that an emergency is happening and you HAVE to do the RIGHT thing so you have to 
.
.
.
take a moment, and think about it. Make the best decision you can.

I hate those moments. 

Then she said, "I'm going to help."

My friend gathered information about the distressed party, seeing how serious it was. I stayed in contact for support and advice, as I've experience with this sort of thing. 

Pretty quickly, they could see that it was an acute mental health event.

Choices needed made, and fast.

I was talking to someone important to me, whom I care about very deeply, but will remain nameless due to the nature of what I'm about to talk about. 

They received a message that their friend was actively distressed, ideating, and selfharming.  

Immediately, crisis mode.

cw// mental health, ideation, selfharm

Today was not 'the best'.

I cried all through writing the gofundme. It was hard to talk about my financial situation and multiple suicide attempts. 

I thought I was done, but today wasn't done with me.

That... fits with our experience. 'a feeling of absence and time passing' a 'feeling someone else has been here'

It's very possible. 
We have several femme/female identifying alters, a couple femme nonbinary, and one fully nonbinary alter who leans towards a soft masc aesthetic.

I would recommend to do research, take time to think about your experience, but...
things like 'what did this woman do to my body?' sound very 'plural' to me. 

It can be scary, but understanding our  brain helped us a lot. We have 9 distinct personalities, I am just one of them.

Plurality is an umbrella term, but it is most commonly self-reported. DID is a specific diagnosis, which I received after self-reporting then having testing done. 
Now, for *us*, we had a severe mental breakdown which made it fairly obvious, but it isn't always so dramatic.

This is a complicated question, because it is very personal. I am a nonbinary trans woman. (She/they) 
but I also have Dissociative Identity Disorder (plurality)
To me that sounds like a plural switch, but... *shrugs*
I'm not really genderqueer, so... I can't directly answer. :C

But, in conclusion:
Yes, DID is real.
No, I didn't want it.
No, I don't enjoy it most of the time.
Yes, there are some advantages.
Yes, there are some disadvantages.

This is my REALITY, a daily struggle, not some thing I do for likes or to look quirky and cool on the interwebs.

And that is why it is so rare to have someone diagnosed as a child. 
Abuse is covered up, often because it was a family member. 
Mental health is a sensitive and misunderstood subject in society. 
and it is only considered a problem if it seriously affects your ability to live.

Moreover, due to alters having different sets of memories, their personalities can develop significantly differently. 

One of my Alters is a Goth, another is a punk. A third likes pink and cute stuff.

It's very relative. 

Most people find out when they have a mental breakdown.

This leads to a situation where you have someone who doesn't have access to all their memories, questions their actions, and frequently avoids things that make them uncomfortable. 

Most people don't realize they have DID, because they have had it all their life.

CW: trauma, abuse
Often they  won't remember the abuse, unless they are triggered into the memories. (these memories will come back later, which is no fun)
Alters form due to the need for the person to function through the abuse, they take over for the traumatized alter.

CW: trauma, child abuse
The abuse usually happens before the child is 8 years old and their personality has finished forming. 
The brain is very adaptable to it's environment, to survive prolonged abuse, it will separate the distressing memories. This creates amnesia barriers.

CW: Child abuse, trauma, violence
And this is where Plurality differs from DID. DID is caused by trauma, not all plurality is. 

For someone with DID, their brain never formed into one personality due to abuse and trauma. They forgot bad memories to protect themselves.

"It just sounds like moods"

It isn't moods, but modes. A neurotypical brain has the same parts as a person with DID, but the parts work as a cohesive unit. There is no strong feeling of separation, no amnesia barriers, no differing personalities.

DID is a defense mechanism.

Moreover, there is a lack of understanding. 
Plurality is an umbrella term, it covers several types of people with 'multiple personalities/souls/etc' in their body. 

DID is a medical diagnosis that covers a specific expression of plurality, but it is by no means the only one.

I've had family members say, "You don't have enough trauma to have DID."

No, I just never told you about the trauma. 

"There are so many Trans plural catgirls, it's just a fad." 

No. Like being LGBT+, people now have language to explain things they didn't have words for.

This tweet brought to you by all the people who have questioned my DID diagnosis.

I have Dissociative Identity Disorder. It is NOT FUN. I didn't want to be like this, I didn't choose this.

Reminder: I had DID since childhood. You don't have to have a diagnosis to be valid!!!

Stop questioning peoples' medical diagnoses!! 

If someone tells you they have a medical condition, they are usually being vulnerable with you. Sharing something personal. 

Questioning the validity of that condition pushes them away and tells them you aren't supportive.

*sniffs decanter, takes a sip*
vaguely smoky, with a hint of derealization... 

...oh wait, that's me.

I'm not complicated.

I have plans for my life. They are very simple, I mean to make good art, support my loved ones, and try to do good for others. 

My biggest fear? *laughs* 

Not being loved.

I'm that simple.

So, I'm going to be good to those I love and hope that's enough.

'More healthily' means I try not to put myself down as much, or be passive aggressive. 
I try not to complain like the world is ending. 
I try to see things as they are, not as my depression twists them to be.
same goes for expectations.

I try to keep them realistic.

CW: mental health

I used to post whenever I was massively depressed, to 'let it out' to vent to the world what I couldn't vent to friends because there was no one to listen.

I try to do that as little as possible now.
Moreover, I try to do it differently.

More healthily.

How to survive- 
1. be willing to fight when you have nothing but stubbornness left to fight with. 
2. recognize and accept your failings and get back up and try again. 

Because you will fail yourself, you will mess up friendships, you will do things you regret.

Get back up.

When I cannot be arsed to care anymore, I go by my cheat sheet. 
Which is my morality. 
Sure, I don't want to care, but I do know I will care again eventually. So I force myself to act as if I do care. 
The pretending often helps me actually feel emotion and break the depression.

CW: depression. 
There come a point in depression where you just don't have the energy to care anymore.
This is when things get dangerous.
You no longer fight your own negative impulses, you no longer take care of yourself, you spiral into a 'don't care' void.
And there you stay.

Congrats.
We earned this.

So how do we decide what is right and wrong? How do we live as a society? 
By using your damned brains and not listening without thinking. Yes, we get emotionally charged, especially right now, but if we want to change the world, we have to stop being so damned easy to lead.

So. We go for the jugular any time someone steps out of line, but who sets the boundaries? The noisy people who yell loudest. And many of them are yelling for money. Which means they can't be objective, they are compromised, right?
No one is objective, sweetie. 
No one.

You can say, 'my people don't do this! We aren't like [bigoted group] but the truth is: 

We all do it. 

Leftists tell other leftists they should kill themselves for their 'misguided' beliefs and 'bad actions'. The left, in particular, has a problem with purity.

Well, if you are on the right side of history, what is wrong with this? 
Simple. Mob mentality doesn't lend itself to subtlety. Exaggeration and hyperbole rule and people try to one up each other, while dunking on the current target of ire. 

This isn't justice, it is harassment.

The problem with online communities has always been dogpiling. As far back as BBSes, we took our cliques and social in-groups and out-groups online. 
The nature of mob justice is not justice, it is about self-righteousness. It has always been this way.

Reality is unforgiving.

Often, people who need to isolate are forced to endure 'comforting' by friends and family. We say that we are 'better' just to survive until we can actually isolate.

Because when you say, 'I want to be alone' everyone takes it personal.

And EVERYONE thinks they can fix you.

If you think these rules don't apply to you due to your relationship, I'm here to disabuse you of that idea.

Alone means alone.

More often, the person who needs isolation will acquiesce to their friend's demand for attention because they don't want to hurt their friend.

PSA: When your friend says they need to isolate or be alone to recover from overstimulation and stress, it is not the time to keep asking what you can do to help.

This is not time to comfort them, fix the problem, or try to work through issues. 

It is time to LEAVE them ALONE.

Far from lazy. We've fought tooth and nail, through mental breakdowns, abuse, neglect, medical emergencies, and financial instability to be lazy.

We escaped. 
Now we just need a little more help while we pull ourselves out of the pit.

So someday, we can help others do the same.

Now that we are actually asking?
We were able to change our life, just by being able to do what we wanted on our terms.

We were able to leave the place that was killing us slowly and hopefully move on to a self-sufficient life. 

Get a job.
Get medical care.
maybe get a dog.

So when we get a message from someone saying we are 'lazy' and 'trying to bilk others' ...
Well, Maeve got upset and had to go away for a while. 
 and I? We are pissed off. 

Maeve worked so hard. She tried her best. She sacrificed everything to just survive.

By the time we were WILLING to ask for help, we had been living in a closet for over 5 years, 20k in debt, unemployed, and literally dying.

The issues that put me in the hospital? They are bad. Not 'dying tomorrow' bad, but bad. 

I need special care.
For the rest of my life.

Many, many times I've tried to crawl out of this hole alone. Jobs, side hustles, novel publishing, commissions, day labor, freelancing etc. 
I never made it out of the hole. A mental or physical health issue would rear up and remove most of our progress.
But we never gave up.

We have been underemployed or physically unable to work for years. Ever since we became a diabetic. We should be eligible for disability, but we are not.

The standard of care I received in Idaho as embarrassing. It never allowed me to rejoin society as a productive member.

We survived by severe austerity. Our glasses are broken and a decade old. We have massive dental issues, poor health and nutrition, basically haven't done anything 'frivolous' in years unless someone else paid for it.

We only have shoes because our son bought them for us.

The tl;dr of the message was: You are lazy and you expect people to take care of you.

And I'm like 'listen, bitch'...

I've lived on less than $200 a month for the last 5 years. Trying to afford medications, food, and everything else. 

We asked for help when we ran out of THAT.

And you know what? That's okay, up to a point. It's fine not to engage with others, it is perfectly understandable not to help people in need just because you don't want to. 

What's not okay is trying to make them feel bad about asking because you feel bad about not helping.

ICYMI: I finally talked about being #plural and how plurality and DID affect us. 

CW: Mental Health, sexual assault, anxiety, vehicular accident, identity, and dissociation.

#pluralgang https://t.co/frMkRnmWKf

And by real, I don't mean you have to care. I mean that it's something that has been researched, studied, and while rare,  it affects something like 1% of the population. 

We are just lucky, I guess. 

So, going forward, I have no idea what to say. Just that it'll be different.

We didn't understand this any more than we understood we were transgender.

And we each have different approaches to that. I'm definitely nonbinary, but the rest of my headmates are transfemme.

In conclusion: This is still new for us and we are working things out. But it's real.

And... Maeve didn't want any of this. She is still nervous about talking about it, which is why I am. 

Dissociation, switching, used to be random. When we were stressed or when a memory would make us feel a certain way. 

Maeve did her best to suppress us.

I don't blame her.

Maeve
Cerrami (me)
Mae 
and Alison. 

Why so many? who knows. I'm not an expert on plurality and I still have a lot to figure out about how this affects us.

Like everything, it's a work in progress.
We are a lot alike, but we all have our own desires and preferences.

And this goes back to childhood. Some of us have memories going back to then. 

We also share memories, because nothing can ever be simple. The amount we share memories varies. There are hard divisions between some alters. 

How many of us are there? Let me introduce you:

So, what does this mean?

First, a bit of vocabulary: 
Host- the 'main' or most active personality.
Alter- other personalities within the body.
Switching- Changing from one alter to another. 

Maeve is the host, she's traditionally been in control most often. 

But there others.

Each dissociation was a lost of time to Maeve or a fuzzy memory. Her anxiety rose and she discussed her worries with her therapist. 

This was back in May. 

Things have progressed rapidly since. We've decided to embrace our plural nature, because integration at our age is rare.

After the Bus accident, after she was groped, Maeve dissociated each time. Not into me though, but into someone who could handle the stress and protect her. 

Someone who could handle the accident and being assaulted. 

But Maeve had been in denial and she got real scared.

First, I'm not Maeve. I'm Cerrami. When things got bad this year, really bad, Maeve dissociated. She retreated into her mind. 

Dissociation is a mental defense when things get too hard. Everyone does it to some extent. Someone with DID can dissociate into another personality.

What's a plural system? it is one body with multiple personalities, or people, that share it. 

There are multiple causes for this. In our case, we were diagnosed with Dissociative Identity Disorder, due to Trauma and PTSD. 

We were diagnosed in February. But we knew already.

I can't sleep. 
Or more precisely, we can't sleep.
It's finally here: the Plural thread. 

This will be a thread on how I currently understand plurality and how it relates to *us*, not all Systems. So, like everything: There are a lot of ways to be plural. 

#pluralgang

And time is running out.

Going to the ER twice in the last couple months has obviously screwed my work schedule. I'm behind on everything, but I've managed to keep publishing stories every month. 

If almost dying doesn't disrupt my publishing schedule, I doubt anything will.

Getting vocational rehab and job training will require travel, possibly moving, definitely money I don't have.

I was desperate before, now I'm kinda screwed, but I'm determined. 

I've got a book and a couple short stories coming out. I have other projects, but they take time.

The list of minor tragedies keeps piling up, to the point I've given up hope that things will change. I've just got to push through and survive. 

Disability is going to be denied, again. I don't have food stamps for medicaid. I can't even get medicaid until January of next year.

I was admitted for Diabetic Ketoacidosis (DKA). The last time I had that, I got medical leave from work and laid in bed for over a month. 

I don't have that luxury this time. My support system is unable, or unwilling, to help. I don't blame them, they have their own problems.

Needless to say, I've been stressed as hell and I'm not remotely recovered. Last night, after only doing light housework, I had to take a nap, which turned in to sleeping until almost 1 am. 

But, the new diet and insulin dosages are working. It will just take forever.

I left the hospital with a pile of papers. New insulin regime. New strict diet. Limited activity. Mandate to reduce my A1C, gain 30 lbs, and get more blood tests.

That means: more syringes, more test strips, actually buying food.

All in a $140 budget. It's literally impossible.

Where we are at: The cost for my visit to the intensive care unit is over 20k. I've submitted it for debt assistance. I was told to expect it to be denied, twice. 

While I wait to be denied, I'm up to 4 doctors apts a month and have changed my medications and dosages.

This is a good thing. I feel better than I have in months, even weak and tired from DKA. Very little nausea, more energy, better Blood Glucose numbers. 

I'm hopeful. 

I'm just angry it took over 25k and almost dying again to learn how to take my medication correctly.

So, I know how I got here. I know why things are this way. But it doesn't help. It doesn't fix anything. 

I *can* fix things. Currently, I have a new diet and know how to follow it. I have new medication dosages and a new insulin equation. 

It seems to be working.

I didn't buy ketone strips to check my acidity, because poor. I didn't check my blood glucose as much as I should have, because poor. I didn't buy my own food, haven't been able to for longer than I want to admit, so I ate what I had access to.

Which wasn't my 'prescribed diet'.

Up until recently, I had fairly good A1C's. My markers looked okay. I didn't know I was constantly starving myself because I had my insulin ratios off.

Why? Lack of money, lack of understanding, lack of attentive healthcare. I'm not mad at my doctors, but I realize their limits.

Fast forward to now. I've been fatigued, nauseous, underweight, and frequently ill for about three years.

Three years of going to the doctor, having these problems and reviewing my insulin and being told 'no change needed'.

So I survived, but not well. Not with the education or the health plan I needed to succeed. I had trouble working, managing my diabetes, and trying to maintain my responsibilities. 

I got sick a lot, I couldn't work.

I read books, blogs, forums, looked at insulin calculators, read everything I could find. And there was a lot to read, plenty of it completely wrong. 

Eventually, I got in with my current clinic and began to get better, but... It's a residency. They had less experience than I.

My first year as a diabetic was me learning how to not die. 

Scraping knowledge from people who assumed I knew what I was doing and didn't have the patience to teach me. I reached out to my Type 1 Diabetic cousin. 

She never got back to me.

I was uninsured. The hospital referred me to the local diabetes education center and assigned me a doctor. 

I got 1 diabetes training session, for $600, and a doc who told me to inject my insulin wrong. 

I spent 6 months doing everything wrong, until I was hospitalized again.

I've been diabetic for 12 years. Since the winter before I turned 30. It was a fun Christmas that year, let me tell you. 

I was told I was diabetic by a doctor who was trying to shame me for 'not managing my diabetes'. 

Me: I don't have diabetes.

He left quickly after that.

Okay. So. Story time. 
I've almost died twice recently and both of them are due to negligence on my part, no matter how you look at it. 

Does this mean I'm trying to qualify for the Darwin Awards? Hardly. 

Let's look at how we got here: I have diabetes and mental illness.

The thread broke, I can't be arsed to fix it. I'm sorry.

That was a week ago Friday. It's Sunday morning. 
I've tried to rest, to remain positive. There are good things and people in my life. 
I just have so little left to fight with. 
I'm beyond not okay.
and I'm probably not sleeping again. 
but I am damned if I'm going to give up.

I didn't tell anybody at first. I didn't know what to say. 
That Friday, I ate some leftover fried rice from a Chinese takeout that one of my parents left on the counter half the night and I got food poisoning. 
I spent most the weekend in a lot of pain and vomiting.

I just kinda stopped. 
reacting. feeling. 
My doctor explained next steps, I think. Things I could do to slow the neuropathy, or something. Health stuff.
But I know what she meant, I am going to lose my legs someday. 
The damage is already there, all I can do is slow the process.

I have diabetic neuropathy in my lower legs. I knew things were bad, but... I had no money and no insurance but.. I don't heal right anymore. I don't even feel it when I hurt myself sometimes. I have random mystery cuts and bruises. They take months to heal. Months.

Later that week my doctor called, after receiving my discharge papers. The ER doctors had seen the wounds on my legs and she had concerns. She scheduled another appointment and more blood tests. 
I went to the appointment, they gave me the diabetic foot physical and poked me.

When I got out, I was exhausted and I hurt, but my son came over for his weekend. He was worried and wouldn't take no for an answer. He's 15 and he spent most the weekend taking care of me while I laid on the couch. 
I cried myself to sleep all weekend.

The rest gets blurry. I got to the hospital. My parents showed up. I got a room. I got an IV and they made me eat. My blood sugar dropped to 40. The nurses started getting very concerned. 
I ate more food. 
Eventually, I stabilized and, as soon as they could, they discharged me.

As soon as I'd done it, I realized my mistake. I normally only take 3-4 units. 15 was enough to kill me 2-3 times. I told Cyndi what I had done and hung up. 
I called my parents, they were across town, so hung up and I called my sister. She was home. 
I chugged a sugared soda.

I prepared a syringe for longterm insulin, 15 units, but I grabbed the wrong vial and drew fastacting insulin instead. 
I have a system. I've been diabetic for 12 years. I'm very careful. But I was distracted, exhausted, stressed, had a blood sugar over 400, and was panicking.

My brain was fuzzy and I hurt. I had hyperglycemia, my blood sugar was through the roof.
I needed my longterm insulin and I needed to eat, to take meds, which meant more insulin. 2 syringes. I started preparing syringes while I worked out a revised plan with my ex over the phone.

On the day I went to the ER, I hadn't been sleeping well for almost a month, maybe more. I had passed out around 5-6 AM.
The phone woke me up, my ex calling me because I was supposed to be at her house to help with things and pick up my son.
I was over 3 hours late on my insulin.

Between nightmares and anxiety, I couldn't relax. I kept expecting something bad to happen, something new. something else. 
There was no time to break down. I had family responsibilities. I was trying to finish stories for my Patreon and Wattpad.
I stopped calling the job back.

A few days passed. I tried to keep it together. 
The job interview got rescheduled again, they said that the person who was supposed to interview me got sick. Whatever.
The guy I was seeing broke up with me. It was complicated, I don't really blame him, but it hurt. A lot.

After a couple minutes convincing, I got her into my father's car and off to the ER.
I went home and passed out. I think that's when the nightmares started. I'm moderately self-aware, I have depression. I already knew I was falling apart. I had scheduled an extra therapy session.

I woke her boyfriend, who was also drunk. He had no idea what happened. 
Then I did the best I could to clean her up and access the wound. I have a fair bit of first aid training. I quickly knew she needed stitches and had a concussion, but no broken bones.
I called our parents.

I woke up my parents, in case my son woke, and trotted over to my sister's place with a bag full of bandaids, gauze pads, and alcohol swabs. 
I figured she had some cuts and scrapes. 
No big deal.
When I got there, she had a gash in her temple and blood all over.

Unfortunately, the night wasn't over. I couldn't sleep. At 2 AM, I started getting texts from my sister. I ignored the first couple, I didn't even look at the phone. She was freaking out because she had hurt herself and couldn't get the bleeding stopped. 
Mind you, she was drunk.

the following Saturday, I was sexually assaulted at a friend's house. A woman I know grabbed my breasts and squeezed them until they were bruised. It barely lasted a moment, I freaked out, started yelling and left. I've since confronted the person, but it didn't resolve anything.

I was supposed to have a job interview and a date that evening, I didn't make it to either. There was a family emergency soon after, which I won't detail here, as it's not my story and private, but I started having trouble sleeping.

I rescheduled the job interview and the date.

The bus accident happened a week later. I don't exactly know how it happened. The bus I was riding in hit a van in front of us. It was a low-speed accident. I was thrown into the seat in front of me. While I was only bruised physically, I had another anxiety attack.

The bartender 86'd the whole group. thankfully. 
I was on a date, but my date hadn't been there at that second. He was supportive and sympathetic. 

It was my first date in years.
I couldn't hide in the bathroom. 
So I got really drunk and made a fool of myself instead.

I got groped in a bar, big whoop. I pretended to shrug it off at the time. Even though I had an anxiety attack and hid in the (Men's) bathroom. Even though his friends laughed and made fun of me because I am transgender. 

I pretended I was okay.

I really wish I were exaggerating.
[CW: mental health, sexual assault, medical, gore]
I feel like it started with the bus accident. I wasn't badly hurt, but I was bruised and scared, and I had an anxiety attack. I'd already been on edge, b/c I'd been assaulted in a bar recently.

This isn't about pity or getting sympathy for more money. I really am screwed or I wouldn't ask. 
This is about how I got to the state where I could inject the wrong insulin and had to rush to the ER. 
By the time that happened though, I'd already had multiple traumas recently.

I can't sleep. I tried, twice. 
I feel miserable about having to ask for money. But... that's not what's keeping me awake. 
My therapist encouraged me to journal, but it isn't helping. 2019 has been like a personal hell. 
I'm a writer by nature and profession, so I'm gonna whine.

The local pride festival parade was this morning. 

I didn't go.

I spent most of the day cleaning house and being all adult. 

It would have been nice, but... *shrugs* 

Instead, I took a long bath and ate pizza. That's good trans content right?

I'm sure someone has said this, but: 

If you like something ironically, you still like it.

But I also like running my characters through metaphorical, and sometimes physical, meat grinders. 

I also enjoy this, but I love horror. Movies, books, comics, stories. Yes, count me in!

Anyway, writing horror. Not as depressed anymore. 

Woo. #yayme

Anyway, art doesn't have to come from pain. Some art DOES and that's okay, but  you don't have to suffer for your art. 

In most of my writing, the dog doesn't die, there is a happy ending, and the heroes win. 

I like writing that stuff. It makes me happy.

The most annoying thing for me is realizing what caused me to get depressed. 

Now, don't get me wrong, it took years of therapy to work out a lot of that stuff. I'm happy for the knowledge, but it also frustrates me. 

Because now I'm like, "Really? That's what made you sad?"

I've been fairly busy, and fairly depressed, lately. This is normal operating procedure, so I haven't really been worried about it. 

One of my ways of dealing with depression is to write horror. 

I know, that might be weird, but it kinda cheers me up. 

Anyway, writing horror.

I'm okay, I have depression,  but part of the reason I am okay because a lot of people helped me. 

If you are unable to beat the darkness alone, most of us can't, ask for help. 

There's no shame in that, and it's better than beating yourself up.

No truly bad person thinks they are bad

Back when I would have described myself as such, I was dealing with a lot of pain, and needed help. 

The brain likes to lie to us and... it is hard to function when you are in pain. 

Don't be too hard on yourself.

Sometimes starting over is running away from stuff, sometimes it's running towards stuff. I've started over many times and it's never easy. 

Just know that you aren't a horrible person and... well, we all get it wrong before we get it right. 

<3

Okay. You can try to run it with the battery out- if you have a removable battery- if that works, replace the battery and you will be fine. but... with the spark earlier, I'm not sure that's a great thing to test. 
It might be that the solder for the charger cracked/broke.

Well, you've cleaned it and tried two different cables, you've done great trouble shooting. 
I'd try a different charger if your sister's is compatible. 
And I'd still reset the SMC/PRAM, because it can actually help with charging issues. If it doesn't, it won't hurt anything.

The battery is probably old and losing capacity. It's... common in laptops. 
A bad battery can cause problems with charging. What I recommend is resetting the PRAM. It can help with many issues, including resetting some battery settings. If that doesn't help, continued-
Okay. I used to be an Apple Tech.  Macbook pro- Does it have enough battery to boot, will it boot without being connected to the power adapter?

Obviously, it's not a huge thing, but it's been there for over a decade. 

Which makes me think it's a limitation of the original software design. Information updates only through sync. 

Apple, I think it's time you killed sync.

Moreover, if you play a podcast, then say, disconnect the phone and later reconnect it, itunes(on the pc) will remember where you left off, but the PHONE won't. 

Maybe it will if you sync, but that's another 10 minutes and a huge inconvenience.

iTunes is so weirdly coded. I'm sure it's a legacy thing, but your podcasts DON'T sync whether they've been played if you play them from your device (i.e. phone via usb) using itunes. 

Which is really annoying and inconvenient. Twelve years, this feature has existed. XD

If I get TOO scared I can always play Raid Mode.

Raid mode is a wave/level based challenge mode. It can be hectic, but it's not scary. It is also pretty good practice for when I get back to the campaign.

Anyway, Resident Evil Revelations and Revelations 2 are on sale currently.

Anyway, I've been playing Resident Evil Revelations 2 and... It's vaguely scary, but having an NPC character with you, in game, makes me feel less scared.

It's like having a security blanket. I'm not alone.

Whenever I play one of 'solo' sections, I get super nervous.

It's fun.

I like being scared, I love horror as a genre. It's one of my favorite things to watch or read for pure escapism. 
 
Ofc, I'm interested in the story of horror games. I could just watch a walkthrough (and have) but I want to have the experience.

So I keep trying to play horror.

I LOVE horror movies, but I have a hard time playing horror games.

For example: I had an exceptionally difficult time playing the beginning of Bioshock and it's not really horror.

I've never finished Dead Space. I am not sure I'll ever play Amnesia.

The problem is: I want to.
To be fair, that's my fault.

The problem is 'NSFW' is a shorthand for 'socially acceptable' and we know some people think two girls kissing is NSFW, while a man and a woman kissing isn't.

Some clarification would not go amiss, eh ? https://t.co/rshmR257dB

Exactly. 

When one group has the ability to define what is acceptable for everyone that will always end in othering and discrimination.

I completely agree.

The impression I get from these types of articles is that the writers would prefer people stop making them uncomfortable around their cis/straight friends.

Respectability politics is insidious and cruel by nature. It's selfish and myopic.

Btw, I LOVE the term queer and use it to describe myself.

But it does no good to call our movement Queer or Q when it's intersex babies being mutilated and trans people being murdered. 

Intersectionality is about INCLUDING EVERYONE so we can HELP EVERYONE.

Why is this so hard?

So, in conclusion, think bigger.

Think better.

If we let ourselves get fooled into thinking that we can win people back with a label, then you have a serious lack of understanding of how we gained civil rights and protections in the first place. 

It's not a popularity contest.

The LGBTQIA+ movement is world wide. This isn't just about being a good citizen and a patriot, this is about equality, healing, and acceptance for all of our siblings. 

That includes everyone. Yes, even the bigots we can save from themselves. 

It's about making a better world.

This work is generational. Frank Kemeny was just one voice. There are so many: Barbara Gittings, Baynard Rustin, Harvey Milk, Sylvia Rivera, Martha P Johnson, Audre Lorde, Christine Jorgensen. 

The list goes on and on, and that's just in the U.S.A.

I'm sure Mr. Rauch understands that, but what he doesn't appear to understand is that sanitizing the movement will inevitably hurt the most vulnerable among us.

Our strength is in unity and shared purpose. We gain acceptance through shared humanity, not shared identity.

Why? Because it doesn't work like that. The ability to gain civil protections relies on raising public consciousness through discomfort. Though protests, through learning, through exposing discrimination, hate crimes, and taking action against them.

His argument is that identity politics have turned the masses away from civil rights protections and into the arms of racists and bigots. 

This is the argument used for decades against feminism. "If it's about equality, why not call it equality?"

It was bull and it's bull now.

There is nothing new about the idea that making ourselves more palatable to bigots will gain us acceptance. 

Civil Rights, world wide, have never been won by making the majority comfortable. 

Anyone who claims to know their history should know better. https://t.co/CfzZ36FCbs

Day decided it didn't matter and shot both the thugs in the head in rapid succession. Doctor Obie hit his head on the ground when the big guy went down, but Day still considered it a success. 
It only took a moment to get the good doctor out from under the corpses.

‚ÄúWe told you, we don't work for Grease. You need to pay us to protect you from us.‚Äù The larger man said. He was holding Doctor Obie up by his ankles. Day tried to imagine why anyone would spend that much of their point allotment on physical strength.

Nor was he terribly enthusiastic about the situation, so he hung back in the shadows and watched.
‚ÄúI told you, I paid Grease this month,‚Äù Doctor Obie cried, staring at the bone saw that the smaller man kept turning on and off.

#Shortstory #Cyberpunk In Day's experience, nothing was ever simple. If something was simple, it was a trap, a lie, or a scam. So, when he found two men holding Doctor Obie upside down and taunting him with a bone saw, Day was not surprised.

If their body discomfort isn't about their gender, then it's dysmorphia, not dysphoria. 
Ideally both people should see a doctor, but honestly I'm not debating individual or edge cases. 
I'm saying it's possible to be trans without dysphoria. Not as common maybe, but possible.

I have dysphoria and it sucks.

Dysphoria is one of the reasons that transgender people transition. Dysphoria has to do with feeling discomfort or disconnection with your body, and some trans people don't experience that.

Each person's experience is different, but no less real.

Hi.
#NationalComingOutDay
It's okay to be gay.
You don't need dysphoria to be trans. You don't need HRT, GRS, or to transition to be valid.
Nonbianary and agender people are valid.
If you are bi or pan, even if you are dating someone of the opposite sex you are still bi or pan.

I promise I WILL be okay. 
This is one more step on a path I chose long ago. 
I will try not to be depressed and distant, but I also don't intend to fill my feed with unhappiness. 

I love you all.

I may still fail. 
There are things I just can't control.
So I hedge my bets, my well-being for the lives of others. 
I plan for disasters that I intend to prevent. 
I ask myself, "What are you willing to sacrifice?" and answer.
And I hope that the storm will pass before I break.

I schedule my therapy appointment. 
I renew my meds. 
I triage my current plans to accommodate the new reality. 
I add more downtime, hoping it will be enough.
I know I'm scared. Right now, though? I don't feel it.
It's there, just beyond reach, but I cannot feel anything.

Now that the threat has past, I'm numb. 
I'm not in shock, I'm in KNOW. 
This isn't the end, I have to keep vigilant. 
This is a marathon, it won't be won in a day or a year. 
There's no room for mistakes, failure is absolute.
I must bend, because I cannot break.

When they returned, Danny indicated it was clear his way. 
Terry nodded, same. 
Progress was slow, but they stuck to the system.
They could have gone around, the campus looked empty. Terry, however, was always wary of unseen eyes.
It was bad to be stuck out in the open.

He beckoned for them to follow.
Terry moved first, checking the rooms as she passed. Andre and his sister, Mary, followed. That left Sam with Johnny. Johnny shrugged and Sam crept forward. When they came to an intersection, Danny scouted one way as Terry went the other.

He walked lightly, his sneakers making little noise on the waxed tile. His baseball bat was in his right hand, as always. Despite his bravado, Danny was being careful. 
They all were.

Danny walked right down the center of senior hall, totally unafraid. It was morning outside, bands of light streaking through the darkened halls. Dust motes swirled as Danny passed. None of them had been there since last year. #amwriting #horror

And... it all clicks into place. The same woman I fell in love with and had a child with, who is still my closest friend, was the girl who completely owned the High Score on the Ms. Pac-Man at the Fun Spot. 
Life is weird. 
She's still better at games than me.
So is the kiddo.

I laughingly comment that I tried to get all the high scores in the valley. The video game witch giggles and says, "I used to play Ms. Pac-Man all the time." 
and proceeds to tell me about spending summers with her Great Aunt and playing Ms. Pac-Man at the Fun Spot.

We have a kid together, but in the end we go our separate ways. We remain friends, co-parent, and talk all the time. 
One day, my mom is telling the story, again, about how people used to watch me play Pac-Man at the pizza parlor and give me money to keep playing.

Together, we 100% the original Spyro the Dragon, beat Final Fantasy VII, VIII, IX and so many more. She's an JRPG and Classic Arcade Queen. She makes people cry when they play Bushido Blade against her.

We play tons of video games together. Some of the best co-op and competitive gaming of my life. 
Best friends. 
Eventually I realize that she's way better than I am. I mean, there are some things I play better, but she's a consummate gamer and I'm a total tourist.

Fast forward ten years. The video game witch and I are still friends, but life took us in different directions. We meet up again at another party, but this time we are both single. 
We start dating, it gets very serious.

Tekken, Primal Rage, Killer Instinct(C-c-combo Breaker!), Mortal Kombat. We mostly stuck to the fighting games. The witch didn't beat everyone, every time, but she won way more often than she lost. 
Some of my friends had a serious problem with this and would avoid playing her.
Later that fall, she starts coming to SCA dance practice in the SUB(Student Union Building), before dance practice, a lot of us liked to play video games in the arcade. So, we play some video games.

Fast Forward to teenage years. On Halloween, I go to meet friends at a punk show. (Dressed as the Crow, it was the 90's.) I'm introduced to a cool college chick who is a witch. (oooh, older girls!)

The witch is super cool and we become friends.

As a kid, High Scores mattered. I played every arcade machine within biking distance. There were few places to play games, and no online games at all. It bothered me that I could never knock off the High Score, but as the years passed, I forgot about it.

Across town, in Julia Davis Park, was the Fun Spot, which had paddle boats and stuff, and a Ms. Pac-Man machine. No matter how much money I poured into that Ms. Pac-Man, I couldn't beat the high score. I couldn't get number one.

#truestory  As a kid, I loved #PacMan. (Ms. Pac-Man is best, but... I love 'em both.) I used to play all the time. I dominated the high scores of the arcade and pizza parlor, (Keystone Pizza, I miss you!) but there was one high score I couldn't beat.

It doesn't matter. 
The end reinforces the dichotomy: The news says D'Va the hero wins without taking a scratch and then takes a much earned break. 
In reality, Hana Song is rebuilding her MEKA with multiple casts. 
Hana knows everyone is counting on her.
She won't let them down.

Why doesn't she wait? "If we don't do this thousands of people will die!" Not because she's overconfident of victory, but because she believes she has no other choice. 
At no point does D'Va have to be reminded of her responsibility. She ejects knowing she'll probably die.

Which makes sense. She was a pro-gamer, winning championships at 16? She's only 19 now.  
When the enemy arrives, she knows that back up can't get there in time, that's why she doesn't wait. 
She's made her choice once she leaves the MEKA bay.

The short gives D'Va fans what they want: D'Va kicking ass. 
It starts by showing D'Va as the world sees her, a star, a national hero. 
Then shows us the real Hana Song.
"This is where the magic happens!" She's a workaholic, a gearhead, and a nerd.

So, forever after, if I shared the drawing, I shared a cropped version, not the entire picture. 

My point? Sometimes critics are wrong.

I remember a conversation I with a friend about a picture I drew of a woman wearing a tight fitting pleather top. 

The breasts bubbled up over the top a bit. 

I was told it was unrealistic. 'breasts don't do that.'

The thing is: I used reference.

See how easy it is? Anybody can do it.  
Now, writing a story is a little more complicated, obviously, but knowing your characters will help you know their reactions to events in the plot. Ideally, they will drive the plot due to their own agency. 

That's good storytelling. ;)

And you do the same thing for environments. Going to write her at work? You've got an office full of characters. Now, if they are bit characters, you can lean on simplicity a little. 

She'll have a work friend, a supervisor, maybe a hated rival. who is also a love interest?

I imagine she's smart and sassy. Used to being dismissed so she's a little snarky and loud. Her professional life looks perfect, but she is awkward in personal relationships.

I could go on, but we already have a character. She could go anywhere from here. Anywhere.

What's her family like? Does she have siblings? Where did she come from? 

Filling in the details isn't that hard. She's driven. 
Was she the first person in her family to go to college or was it expected? 
She competed with her brother her whole life, they both went to college.

Did she get everything handed to her or did she have to earn it? How does that affect her feelings towards her job? Does she love it or hate it? 

For me, I like to make earnest characters, so my girl, she's driven, worked her way through college, and is now climbing the ladder.

Young enough that she's not on top, but has been working for a while in her field. She may be respected, or reviled, but she's not famous. 

Or she could be. Depending on what you want the story to be. Riffing on her past gives us an idea to her motives. Is she lazy or driven?

People are history in motion. We are our experiences, our preferences, our pain, our loves, our fears. Your characters need to reflect that complexity, or at least suggest it. Find your character's history. 

She's a professional, that means she had to work hard to get there.

Our twenty something lady is going to be a professional. She's got skills. But her life is a mess. Why? Because no one is perfect, no one is without weaknesses, pain, trauma, challenges, and habits. 

People will call these quirks. Don't fall into that trap. People aren't quirks.

Does that mean Captain America is better than Wolverine morally? Wolverine would argue that Cap is an idealist and he's a realist. A pragmatist, even. Maybe. 

Anyway, characters should have their own morals and beliefs, even the villains.

Conversely, Wolverine(Logan, Jimmy.) will perforate your spleen if you catch him in the wrong mood. 

But Logan is a different type of hero. He'll protect the weak from the strong, because he can take it, but he'll also make decisions that Cap couldn't consider.

Few good characters are uncomplicated, if any. Take Captain America, or Superman, because, really, they are similar. Both are the Ultra Competent Hero. Both are constrained by their morality. 

Sometimes, they have to make terrible decisions, but they stand by their ideals.

There are several archetypes and tropes for the protagonist. They can be the ultra competent hero, the naive, unprepared hero, or even the hopeless bumbler. 

While you don't, and really shouldn't, just build characters around a simple archetype, it helps to know them.

There are, however, good practices. Characters in stories are often archetypal, which is both good and bad. Audiences expect the hero to act a certain way, the villain as well. 

This can be a boon, but relying on archetypes can lead to cliched characters and stories.

Characters will change over time, indeed they should, but they also change as you create the story. They gain more depth and personality. 

So, let's make our protag a woman. Not a child, but not middle aged. An adult in her mid-twenties. Why? Why not? There are no real rules.

How do we make one? Well, we start by assigning traits and seeing what fits. In an ideal situation, you would have some idea of the story, but often characters come to mind when I don't have a story for them, so YMMV.

Also, it's okay if you don't stick with your first idea.

What does that mean? Well, let's make a character. We'll start with something easy, a protagonist. 

The central character in your story, the protagonist is usually the catalyst of a lot of the plot. The protag is caught up in the story's conflict, emotionally and physically.

Creating a good character is part improv and part understanding people. It's pretending and acting, but by yourself. 

You want a character that is relatable, but not too perfect, while also being compelling enough(or bad enough) that people love(or hate) them.

When it comes to characters, we take observations and we improvise. 

Did you ever act or take drama or improv? No? Did you ever play a tabletop game like D&D? Roleplay on a forum or in a chat?

All of them require acting, imagination, and creativity.

"Where do you get your characters from?" is the question that always confused me the most when people ask about writing. 

Characters are all around us. First, artists of all types rely on observation. We soak in the world around us and we interpret it through our art.

*Explaining my mental illness to a friend*

Friend: That sounds like a personal hell.

Me: Yes, it very much feels that way too.

The United States has been called an experiment and a dream. 

The dream is an ideal, that everyone in the US should have the equal opportunity to achieve success. The experiment is to see if it's possible, to continually strive for that goal. 

If it fails, then it's on US.

So, you have two choices:

1. Continue to do nothing and continue to watch people die. (Because people are dying RIGHT NOW, don't kid yourself.)

2. Do something about it. 

How you ask?

WE ARE THE PEOPLE. 

Individually? We don't have power. Together? We are unstoppable.

Some moderate: You are talking doom and conspiracy theories. 

No, I'm telling you this is their plan. IF nothing else: destroying social protections(SS, Medicare, Welfare), equal rights, abortion rights, etc.

How do I know this? Because they said they'll do it. Repeatedly.

We are the ones who will lose. They will come for our rights, they will come for our medical care, they will come for our children. 

At the same time, the majority will get fleeced and lied to about what the administration is doing. Social Security? Say bye-bye!

The blood on the street from this is, was, and always will, be the blood of the minorities and their allies. Those that can be cast aside without the majority doing anything. 

We'll, the minorities, will suffer and die for it. 

Why? Because we are the ones in the crosshairs.

Now, your argument is: People are protesting, rioting, fighting. 

Yeah, but: The majority of people aren't. 

We hem and haw, we whine and worry, but the majority? 

They think they are safe, protected. That it CAN'T HAPPEN TO THEM. 

And some of them are right.

In the US, we see ourselves as heroes, protecting the world. In actuality, we are complacent and we are myopic. 

The majority of the people won't be moved. 

Unless it gets very, very bad. 

That's our history. That is who we are.

We didn't enter WWII to help the Jewish people or to prevent the Holocaust. WE DIDN'T PREVENT THE HOLOCAUST. Nor hundreds of genocides around the world since. 

We got involved in WWII because we were attacked. That's when we decided to act.

This is the United States. This is how it's always been. Social progress has come from the pain and suffering of those who need it most.

Sufferage? Protest, Riots, Civil Unrest.
Civil Rights? Protest, Riots, Civil Unrest.
LGBT Rights?  Protest, Riots, Civil Unrest.

Why? Because even if we get impeachment, they won't prosecute. The argument will be 'the good of the democracy'. And the public will whine, but not do anything. 

Nothing will actually change. Not enough people will vote.

Either 45 will get elected again, or someone worse.

We'll likely get a new Supreme Court Justice, because the Dems can't stop that either. 

Why? Because the majority is selfish and cowardly. Those that AREN'T won't get enough support to change the tide completely. 

By 2020, it'll be dirty.

And here is how it's going to go down: If we're lucky, we win the midterms in NOV, we flip some seats.

It will look like the Democrats will fight, but they won't. Not to the level that is needed. But, it will stem the tide, they will choose to and be able to stop some things.

Listen, things are getting bad.  

I mean: The US.

And if you are a US Citizen, I'm speaking to you. 

This isn't new, this isn't just '45', or a couple bad actors. 

This is a cultural problem, a social problem, and at this point, a constitutional crisis.

I look at this, and I'm like, "I've said nothing about what would make the game cool." And that's okay. 

The hardest parts, for me, would be creating the progression within the game systems and story. 
The rest is just assets. A lot of assets, but manageable.

The skill system and quest system would have minimal complexity. 
Short scripted events at most, very few 'cut scenes'. 
Primary gameplay loop would be fighting/avoiding enemies, collecting loot, completing quests, finding exit to 'level'. 
I... think I could do this.

The programming would be fairly straightforward.
Enemy state machine/ai.
Character controls(movement, camera)
collision(actor/actor, actor/environ)
item database and uses
skill system
quest system, 
story progression (events, prerequisites, dependencies.)

10-15 unique npcs. (all on same skeleton)
No voice acting(I'm poor)
simple Leveling system, 
skill progression
items(armor, buff items, food, sellable junk, accessories, cosmetics.)
tons of environmental models.(walls, doors, plants, chairs, tables, counters, video screens, etc.)

(Sorry, I can't help but work on this 'outloud'.) 

One large environment(but not huge, like a large building.)
5-7 enemy types. 
Animations(walk, run, interact, open door, pick up, *attack*, reaction(damage), basic 'talk animations', death animation, miscellaneous interactions.)

That is not actually a bad idea. The person in question actively cares about my health.

Oh, they'll 'understand', but knowing the person in question as I do there will be a lot of passive-aggressive hand-wringing.

The good part? I have identified a possible cause, I can change my habits. 

The bad part? I have to find a polite way to tell someone that their food is making me sick.

About six months ago, I started tracking when I got sick as well as blood sugar, injections, and meals. 

I've found that I get sick most on Mondays. Not a surprise, I knew that. 

Also, I've noticed a pattern: On weekends I eat more meals prepared by other people.

Exactly. It's not even an ego thing. I just can't see wasting time with someone who is clearly not enjoying my presence.

Why torture both of us? 

Conversely, being in a relationship with someone who is engaged is great. 

Even shopping together can be fun!  #ImweirdIknow

I call this the "Cheap Trick" philosophy of affection. If the person I want isn't passionately engaged with me, then I'm not liable to maintain interest in them. 

Sure, it sounds selfish, but it's really just self-protection. Why chase after someone who isn't interested?

When I was a teen, I had a crush. She didn't have feelings for me. It sucked, but I didn't dwell on it. When she started dating, I as happy for her.

And that's when I realized:

I want you to want me.
I need you to need me.
I'd love you to love me, 
but if you don't that's okay.

To heal, you have to face those demons. You have to fight your way through them and... find your peace.

You don't have to forgive or forget, but accept. Accepting the pain, learning from it, and then  letting it go.

That's the hard part for me, letting go.

You see, you hid those things from yourself, you became numb to it, to protect yourself. 

Now that you are getting better, that numbness goes away, leaving raw pain. Stuff you never even processed. 

The good part? You have feelings. The bad part? They don't feel very good.

Just a reminder: when you've been in a bad place for a long ass time, your thinking gets screwed up. When you start to get better? All that screwed up-ness comes back, harder than ever. 

This is normal.

You can get through it, you might not think so, but you can.

P.S. The medical center I go to is awesome and the people are great, but it took me years to find them (in the same town). 

If I made more money, the price would go up. 

There's a point in the middle where I'd need insurance I can't afford to get medication I can't afford.

Anyway, to sum up: [tl/dr]

Access to healthcare in the United States sucks.

Prescription Medication prices are horrible. 

I probably have hypoglycemia unawareness.

I almost killed myself (accidentally). 

I'm a liability in the Zombie Apocalypse,

...but not for long. <3

In the Zombie Apocalypse, I'm dead in a two weeks to a month without insulin, which also expires.
 
I'd need a source of genetically modified insulin, which is likely in a zombie-filled laboratory. 

Or a lot of pigs and a lot of specialized equipment.

(I've thought about this.)

I was hurrying to get my appointment because I needed to renew my prescriptions. 

Which I need, or I'll eventually succumb to diabetic ketoacidosis and die. 

I don't fear the zombie apocalypse, I fear losing access to insulin for more than a day. .

I cannot afford Continuous Glucose Monitoring (CGM). 

If I have hypoglycemia awareness, and can't feel when I'm in danger, I can't afford not to have Continuous Glucose Monitoring. 

Because I didn't know that I was a unit of insulin away from accidentally killing myself today.

The only way I afford to live is with help: 

The Pharmaceutical company has a low income program which drops the price on vials from about $500 a month to $10 through the clinic pharmacy. 

The Clinic has a sliding scale so I can afford to have regular appointments and labs.

Had I the access to it, I'd choose an insulin pump and continuous glucose monitoring. But that would require money for the insulin, insurance to make the insulin affordable, and an income to pay for all of that. 

As it stands, medication is more than my income. Let alone eating.

The problem here? Hypoglycemia Unawareness. My body isn't reacting normally to low blood sugar and that's dangerous, especially long term. 

I inject with syringes and test with a finger prick, because I'm poor and can't afford insulin without help let alone an insulin pump.

The blood was taken within five minutes of my visit. Then I waited for my Rx, Read an article, and went to catch the bus. 

I made a phone call, then I ate one of my emergency snacks that I always carry. 

Because I was little bit peckish. 

Not starving, but a little peckish.

I had no idea what my blood sugar was, because, in my hurry to make my appointment, I forgot my glucometer at home. 

I was nervous at my appointment, but I am always nervous at the doctor. I had a little difficulty answering a question, but I thought it was just that, nerves.

I'd be liable to question the test, but I'm pretty sure I know what happened. I injected for a normal meal, but because I was in a hurry, didn't eat enough. 

Reviewing the carbs, I injected 5 units, but ate less than 45 grams carbs.

The doctor called because he was worried af.

At 70, I should be shaky, sweaty, anxious, rapid heart rate, and irritable. 

At 43, I should have confusion, abnormal behavior, poor coordination, and difficulty performing complex tasks.

The closer you get to 0, the closer you get to unconsciousness, seizures, coma, and death.

I'm still at the meeting btw, but my cohort is understanding, as usual. 

He tries to keep me engaged so I won't worry. 

I call back and get the doctor. 

He tells me that my glucose test came back at 43 mg/dL. 

Standard is 100, 70 is hypoglycemia, 54 is clinically significant.

I figure it's not my A1C, because it's usually in range, and they would likely wait until morning. 

One of my meds requires a potassium screen, so I worry about that. 
Then I wonder if they checked my white blood count and it was high. 

40 minutes pass and no call back.

The on-call doc couldn't remember the pager number for the clinic so he left his personal cell phone number in the message and told me to call. 

I call back, leave a message, and worry. 

I know some of what was in my blood panel, so I start the guessing game of what's wrong.

[cw anxiety/medical] I got a call at 10:00 PM. 

I didn't know the number, and I was in a meeting, so I didn't answer. They left a voicemail, so I checked it. 

Just in case.

The on-call doc called to discuss the lab results from my appointment from earlier today. 

At 10:00 PM.
But you accomplished it.
But not any time soon.

After my divorce, I finally got diagnosed with Depression. It would be almost 10 years before I was diagnosed with bipolar disorder. 

Even then, I didn't tell my counselors that I was Trans. I rarely admitted to myself what was wrong. 

It was like a wound that I just ignored.

I didn't know what disassociation was. I mean, I understood the words, but I didn't understand the feelings.

Most of my 20s was spent self-medicating and trying to 'be a better person', because I still felt like a monster.

I tried to be invisible, I tried to fade into the background. Nothing really mattered, because I wasn't really me. 

I tried to get help, but my early experiences with Mental Health experts were abysmal. 

Eventually, this led to binge drinking and drug abuse. Anything to feel.

Coming out as bisexual in high school lost me friends, but no one needed to tell me that being trans would make me the target of ridicule and abuse. 

I was scared. I was suicidal. I thought I was a monster, I thought I was broken. I didn't understand why I couldn't be 'normal'.

And yeah, I knew I was bi/pan at 13. I also knew something ELSE was different, but I didn't have the words for it. That particular feeling had been with me as long as I could remember. 

I knew, but... I couldn't explain or admit it.

So,there i was, making lunch for my 13-year-old, and George Michael's "Freedom" comes on.

I'm crying before he gets through the first lines. 

I know all the lyrics, I know what they mean. "Freedom" was really important to me as a 13-yr-old bisexual.
