My boots are already stained with Nazi blood.
For me, that means fighting back. Violently if necessary, to defend myself and those I love. It's not a choice.
What she meant is, you cannot sit by and let evil happen. You have to confront it or you are an accomplice. You are helping it happen.
She explained, "There are reasons to stand up and fight, even if you are the next one off the bridge."
There was some debate about whether they should be tried as accomplices. My mother was very upset and sat us down to talk.
When I was a teen, a teen was thrown off a bridge and died. There were other people there, in the car, when it happened. They did nothing.
So when people say, 'violence is bad' I tell them the alternative is letting people die. Letting the Nazis win isn't an option.
Mind you, we AREN'T friends and we don't talk, but I still have a lot of respect for my ex-husband. In a fight, we'd be on the same side.
He would tell you, "The only way to make a Nazi shut up is to kick their teeth in!" because he knows it intimately.
I don't know what made him leave, but I know his family and I think that helped. When I met him, he was a feminist and incredibly outspoken.
It wasn't something we talked about extensively. It hurt my heart and it was something he was ashamed of.
Finding a group that accepted him probably gave him the first sense of belonging he had. I don't know.
My ex-husband was one before we met. He grew up in California and, like me, was harassed frequently.
Many people have it worse. If I hadn't been raised by a loving family who was concerned with equality and justice, I could've been a Nazi.
It was only logical, to protect myself. And I consider myself lucky, because I got out of most of those scrapes intact.
That wasn't the only time a knife has been pulled on me. I learned to fight, I wore a leather jacket for protection, and I carried weapons.
This is not a good thing, nor am I proud of it. My choice was letting him stab my friend, or trying to stop him. It still bothers me.
By 3rd grade I had been in a dozen fights, bruises were common. In 8th, I hospitalized another teenager because he tried to stab a friend.
I was attacked because I was too femme, because I was too geeky, because I didn't play sports, and I had long hair.
Even though I have a great deal of privelege, being white, vaguely middle class, I was frequently subject to violence as a child and a teen.
Our society is full of people who have never had to defend themselves. Who have never had their life endangered by another human.
They deserve no power. They deserve no voice. Their only message is death and hate. What they want is for you do DO NOTHING.
Whiteness won't save you from white supremacists. Giving them space only allows them to recruit, to grow, to gain power.
Nazis don't care if you are polite. Their stated goal is to wipe out resistance to their sick beliefs. They want us dead.
When I see people calling for peace, all I can think of is that these people have never faced this enemy.
It took three people beating someone on the dance floor to provoke a response. Only the bouncer(a friend) and another friend came to my aid.
The bouncer might not have noticed(he was often drunk) but... no one else jumped in to help her either.
Now, here's the thing: While her(white) friends got her out of there, no one confronted the neo-nazis but me.
The owner and another person took me to the apartment upstairs and cleaned me up.
I'm pretty sure the bouncer took neo-nazis out back and beat the shit out of them, but I don't know. I never saw them again.
I don't remember a lot from that night, I had a concussion, but there is a clear vision of a spiked gauntlet bashing a neo-nazi in the face.
I couldn't escape, I couldn't effectively fight back. If the bouncer and other punks hadn't saved me, I don't know what would have happened.
I turned the other way in the pit and elbowed the nazi in the face. Later his friends found me and started beating the shit out of me.
Seeing something like that does something to you, or me, at least. I was young, angry, and not willing to stand by and let that shit happen.
For no reason than she was black. I didn't know her, I still don't. Her friends got her out of there fast.
People have heard the story of when I got my face punched in by three neo-nazis. One of them assaulted a PoC in the pit at the Crazy Horse.
I hate violence. I hate every second of it, but if I have to choose between punching a nazi or letting them hurt someone, it's not a choice.
Because I was able-bodied, white, and my father owned a gunstore(police liked me), I was unafraid to punch a neo-nazi.
So, we had to protect ourselves. This meant we got really good at recognizing neo-nazis and their ilk. We learned to fight back.
Punk kids on the street could expect harrassment for standing around, skateboarding, or looking weird. They didn't like us.
The Boise police can be good people, I've had a lot of positive encounters with them, but in the 90's, they weren't punk-friendly.
Because these were punk venues, they often didn't call the police. We had underage kids, runaways, drinking, and drugs.
A common tactic was to target someone and attack people in mosh pits. They would knock someone down and stomp on them.
They harrased PoC, women, anybody they felt like they COULD attack. This meant:yelling insults, throwing things, violence.
As a 90's punk, you couldn't escape Neo-nazis at punk venues. They showed up, even though they weren't welcome.
A well-reasoned thread, I have a few things to say about it. I live in Idaho. We have had a Neo-Nazi problem a long time. https://t.co/RdSdrrxYPY
Anyway, Rant over. This rant was brought to you by: My need to ask a family member for money to get insulin and the shame that goes with it.
Thank you. I don't intend to ever give up, I have good reasons to keep fighting. <3
This is the experience of a white, male-passing, American. If it is this hard for me, I can only imagine how hard it is for PoC and women.
We live in a world that has PLENTY, but we section it off based on income not need. We don't take care of those w/ illness, we punish them.
My point? It shouldn't be this way. I shouldn't have to lie and steal to be able to eat, or help my kids to eat. No one should have to.
'A little better'. I still am only here because my family is kind and supports me. They pay for my therapy, my medication, and help my kids.
Instead of killing myself, I forced myself into therapy and have been there ever since. I'm working on disability and I'm doing better.
Mind you, I'm bipolar, and I was (and am) dealing with other mental health issues as well. Diabetes just made them worse. I wasn't surviving
There was nothing but life and work. I had no time for anything else. I had no energy. Eventually, I just wanted to die.
Every day, I woke up and went to work at 8 AM, then came home at 4 PM and went to sleep. I'd get up for dinner, then go back to bed.
Almost a year ago, I fell apart. I was working, but my soul was tired. I had run out of energy, I felt like a burden and a useless person.
I begged, pleaded, borrowed, lied, and even stole things to make sure I survived, so my kids wouldn't be without a parent.
I vomited in work bathrooms and went back to work with shaking hands and blinding headaches so I knew my kids would eat, so I could eat.
I sold everything I owned of value, I tried every job I thought I could do and several I knew I couldn't, just to get by.
This is the position I've been in for 10 years. My health won't get better, this is maintenance. How do I survive? How do I make ends meet?
Now, I WANT to pay my child support. I WANT to help my children and their mothers. I am not against child support at all.
Which frequently means I'm borrowing money to pay any child support. If I don't, they WILL throw me in jail for contempt of court.
But I owe them 10 of thousands in back child support. I am ashamed of this, constantly. I pay what I can, whenever I have any money at all.
Hell, I am barely able to take care of them. Their mothers(yes, there are more than one) are mostly kind to me because they know I try.
I do have children. I do my best to take care of them, but my contributions are generally more about morals than money. I can't feed them.
And the idea of giving up my stories, any of them, is like asking me to choose which child to kill. I cannot even consider it.
Which is... utterly bullshit. You shouldn't have to worry about WHETHER he will have his medicaid and you shouldn't have to go without.
I could declare bankruptcy, but the kicker there? I'll lose all of my intellectual property. All my stories that I've published. Everything.
I can totally understand that. It's been rough to find any silver lining lately.
I've never been able to pay back those medical bills. I have over $100,000 in medical bills, just to keep me alive.
The first few years I was diabetic, I spent a lot of time in the hospital. I was diagnosed at 29, which is rarer for a type 1.
I don't like to complain. I don't want sympathy or pity. This simply IS my reality. Death or crippling debt.
& I cannot consistently do mental labor. Diabetes causes problems with brain function. This exacerbates my bipolar and anxiety.
This situation makes it incredibly hard to do anything. Most of my days are filled with physical pain. I can't do physical labor, (c)
But, because of our government's inability to see reason, I cannot depend on that. I'm not sure I'll get disability, despite my conditions.
Obamacare didn't resolve this, because I simply couldn't afford Obamacare. Single-payer might not even resolve it. Medicare for all might.
I couldn't even afford that w/o help. I'm alive not because of any safety net provided by our government, but because my family likes me.
So, how do I survive? 1. A low income medical center 2. cheap insulin through a deal with the medical center and the manufacturer.
Why? Because I cannot work full-time or part-time at any job consistently. Not to mention, jobs I COULD get also dodn't provide insurance.
$700 before anything else. Food, Rent, Untilites, Phone, any other bills... all on top of that. Mind you, I have no insurance.
Excluding the Glucagon Kit, those are monthly costs. My average cost for medication, not including Mental Health meds is over $700.
Other supplies: Needles $30, alcohol swabs $4, lancets $5, glucose test strips $20+, keytone strips $10, A Glucagon emergency kit $300.
We need Rxs for insulin, metformin, etc to function and survive. Insulin, w/o insurance, costs $600 a month. Not including other supplies.
For a person with diabetes, seeing a doctor regularly is essential. We need regular testing, to make sure our medication is doing it's job.
Diabetes also exacerbates mental health issues like depression and bipolar.
Diabetes leads to digestive issues, kidney problems, heart problems, blindness, circulatory issues that can lead to amputation.
But for a type 1 diabetic, there is no such hope. External Insulin is required to live. Both conditions cause the body to deteriorate.
Type 2 can go into remission, but it doesn't go away. Most type 2 diabetics that do not require medication closely monitor food and activity
Type 2 diabetics don't always require insulin, but they can, depending on their health and response to meds. Both conditions are uncurable.
A lot of people are more familiar with type 2 diabetics, because there are ~10 times as many of them as there are type 1 diabetics.
That is not hyperbole. My pancreas no longer produces enough insulin to keep me alive. I inject two types of insulin every day to function.
Hi. New peeps might wonder why I am so concerned about healthcare. I'm a type 1 diabetic, that means without injecting insulin, I will die.

And I'm not trying to shame anyone for their sexual attraction. I REALLY mean: I just don't understand it, but, again, I'm bi as hell.
In my experience, all genitals are compatible, but I get your point. Relationships aren't good or bad based on sexual attraction alone.
Genitals aren't gender, per se... and I'm not trying to say that a person can't want one genital type. It just doesn't make sense to me.
This is... basically how I feel. If I was attracted, then genitalia doesn't matter. Attraction requires they meet a basic level of decency.
Now, Now. You had an interesting year, but that doesn't mean your perspective is invalid.
I'm not saying it's wrong to only like one genital set. It just confuses the hell out of me.
I know that many/most hetero people don't 'prioritize body parts' as the most important thing, but it confuses me that it's a deal breaker.
I suspect I *can't* understand. I don't view potential partners' bodies as the MAIN reason I'm attracted to them.
By saying 'I'll only date women who have a vagina/men who have a penis.' Like, okay, I guess, but... why is that the most important thing?
I'm bi/pan, so I've never known those feelings, but I get really confused as to why genitals are more important than personality or morals.
The fascinating thing to me about people prioritizing genitals in their relationships, is that they choose genitals over personality.

Anyway, I finally found the themes and stories I wanted to tell in the second novel. They were always there, I was just afraid to look.
Fabricated Dreams is about Love, Family, Responsibility. It's also about betrayal, greed, and corruption. It's a power struggle for control.
Both are valid questions, but a story is more than what happens next, ideally. Characters change and grow. They learn, they struggle.
'That Time My Brain Exploded' and other stories. Hmm. It has a nice ring to it.
When I sat down to write the sequel, I thought 'what happens next', not 'what does this story to say?' and that was a mistake.
It combined several of my ideas. It hit upon themes which were, and are, important to me. Nothing else spoke to me like that.
I didn't really have another compelling Cyberpunk story. Fabricated Dreams was a combination of several ideas, some old and some new.
Which is, in retrospect, a lot of the reason I dove into writing the sequel. All the writing advice says write 'two in the same genre'.
I dunno what people would call them. *shrugs* 'Episodic short stories'
Some of them will inevitably make it into a collection, others will become longer works. I have a couple serials or short story series.
I have always had tons of ideas, but I had always had trouble FINISHING anything. Fabricated Dreams was the first thing that I finished.
(Which is why I have so many WiP right now.)
Frustrated, I left the series alone for a while. Wrote different things. New things, old things. I let myself make mistakes again.
I went back and read the first book, then I wrote a new treatment of the second novel. It was better, but felt incomplete. I sat it down.
There were good scenes, but ultimately, I discarded the entire draft. It was hard to do, but necessary if I wanted to write a good story.
The plot had been rushed, I had better ideas at the end than I did at the beginning. There was a horribly unnecessary fight between the MCs.
I learned more about writing by editing my first novel than I did by writing it. When I edited the second novel, all I could see were flaws.
So, I have been having a lot of trouble with my second novel. I wrote it before finishing editing the first novel and it shows.

only after you have spent serious time TRYING to see other people's points of view. Trying to understand their perspective isn't simple.

Misinterpretation is rife in online communication, but it also happens face-to-face. Don't assume, be skeptical.
Understanding someone is a complicated effort. It doesn't just happen. Why someone says something is often as important as what they say.
That still doesn't mean that what they are saying is correct, nor does it mean that your interpretation of what they are saying is right.
So, listen, try to understand the meaning, but understand it's amplified by their emotions. Those emotions are valid. They matter.

And yes, I understand the variability of language, this is why you make discussion a normal part of family life. To reinforce core ideas.
Because it isn't actually taught. People are more inclined to pay lip service to morality, but not actually make teaching it a priority.
Then they aren't taught to respect others, in my opinion.
Because they aren't taught that being friends with the object of their affection could be an acceptable outcome. They don't see the value.
My mother was the architect of my moral structure. My father's contributions were more on the self-defense spectrum.
Aye. There was some poor wording there on my part. Friendship is not to be expected, nor forced. Compassion is the goal, on all fronts.
I think that a lot of parents are too scared, too busy(BS), & too self-absorbed to teach their children half the things they need to learn.
If someone doesn't want you, it isn't the end of the world. You can still be friends. You TEACH the value of FRIENDSHIP.
You teach how to accept rejection, the hardest part for teens. Which is hard. I use the 'Cheap Trick' Approach. "I want them to want me."
You teach a child that they can say no, then you help them realize that means other people can say no too, and that's okay.
You then discuss how it's not okay to expect things from people because you are nice to them. You make it normal that consent is required.
You start simple: You ask them if it's okay to have hugs and kisses. If they say no, you don't force it on them.
It really goes with teaching compassion and respect for others. Helping them understand that other people have value was easy, to be honest.
Explaining the concept (to teenagers, I have 3 children) and discussing the reasons why it's important. Then repeating the lesson as needed.
And to be honest, it's not a terribly Zen statement.

The reason I'm proud to be an American are based on the ideal of freedom, justice, and equality. We made that, now we have to defend it.
That's why I say, "Fight however you can." Just because I can't walk or stand long enough to march doesn't mean I'm letting them win.
Notice marching isn't in there. I marched for years, but now I have diseases that limit my ability. I'm a liability in the field.
Fight back however you can. I'm calling my reps, keeping myself sane, and donating what I have. This is for our children, our future.
In our shitty times, it is important to remember the reasons we are fighting: Human rights, equality, justice, love, and, yes, art.

We live in a world where people kill each other to prove the glass was empty. Therefore, it's important to know the glass was always full.
But dismissing something because you don't understand it doesn't make it go away. It just means you need to change your perspective.
Her point was: People tend to see things certain ways. They will dismiss things because they cannot see them, cannot understand them.
I saw the glass as empty, because it just held air. I didn't think of the air, nor did I think of the gaps between the rocks and sand.
She smiled & said, "It was always full. First full of air, then air and rocks, then air, rocks, and sand. Now Air, rocks, sand, and water."
Of course, the water went between the rocks and sand, until it had saturated. She asked, "Is it full?" Being wary, I said, "I don't know."
I replied "It's more full." She responded, "Are you sure?" I nodded. So she said, "Now pour water over the rocks and sand."
Then she asked, "Is it full?" to which I replied, "Yes" "Now pour sand over the rocks until you can't fit anymore sand in. Now, is it full?"
As a child my mother told me a story about perspective. She said, "Get a glass, put rocks in it until it can't take anymore. 1/?

Hello morning. World still here? Okay, I guess I'll get up.
Sometimes, you think you have everything figured out, just to realize that your 16 year old self and 28 year old self were actually right.
You'd think at 38, I'd have me figured out. I thought I did. I made some choices, consciously, that I've found I couldn't with.
I'm not sure what exactly the future holds. I don't have to make that decision yet. I am still just trying to breathe and accept myself.
I guess the main thing I can say is: I figured out why I could never feel happy with my accomplishments and now things CAN get better.
I'm not talking openly, because I don't want to. I know what the problem is, but I spent a lot of time suppressing and denying it.
After accepting some 'inconvenient truths' of my own, I feel a lot better about my path moving forward. Scared as hell, but better.
In the end, I had to talk to a doctor, because I knew I had been suicidal for months. I won't do it, I hate suicide, but I was there.
So, I sat down and thought for a long time. Well, more I listened to my feelings and tried to unravel years of denial and self-hate.
I recognized my feelings and was like, "I resolved this, 10 yrs ago.I don't want to believe this." But... I do my best not to lie to myself.
But suddenly, I had feelings return that I thought I'd resolved and it put years of unhappiness in perspective. I was stunned and scared.
I am bipolar, depression comes with the territory. This was different. I've been terribly unhappy for a long time, accepted it as immutable.

When I think about the fight ahead, I am reminded that a comic book helped me form the basis of my morals. And I'm totally okay with that.
I don't think I'm special; actually, I pray that I'm not. We need people who will stand up, because otherwise we'll get stomped down.
I don't advocate violence. I hate it. But I won't let someone come to harm if I can prevent it. Even if that means facing it myself.
You fight with logic, compassion, understanding, and when you have no choice, you fight with your fists. You protect those that need it.
Even if that meant we were the next person thrown over the bridge. Her meaning was clear: You don't let evil happen, you fight it.
She told us that we couldn't be the sort of person who let someone else get harmed without trying to stop it.
My mother discussed this with us because it upset her. The needless death and the fact that the other people did nothing to stop it.
Story: When I was young, a teenager was thrown off a bridge near where I live. There were other people there who witnessed the incident.
I know that sounds silly, but it's true. I learned to be strong mostly through conversations with my mother, which often included #Xmen.
#Xmen comics stuck with me and gave me strength when people would tell me that I deserved to die, just for being different.
I guess what I'm trying to say is #Xmen had a huge effect on how I saw the world. The idea of fighting, even when the world hates you.
My mother read #Xmen. We discuss the characters to this day.  She gets annoyed when Storm is portrayed as anything other than a goddess.
Growing up as a #queer person in the #80s and #90s, I have a lot of #xmen feels. Kitty Pryde was my idol forever. Yeah, KITTY FUCKING PRYDE!

Honesty and earnestness will get you a long way. I've found people are more willing to help than you'd ever expect.
To be honest, the talking to people was the hardest part for me at first. I was like: I wrote a thing, why doesn't it sell?
'take so much'. Do you have it in you to network, build community, and write when you don't want to? Yes? Then you can do it.
It took me forever to learn that. It IS worth the sacrifice, in my experience. Never been happier and I'm not even rich. :)
Be respectful, learn all you can, and be open-minded. It's good advice for a writer or any person. That's about it. *kicks soapbox away*
Does that mean research? Yes. Does that mean asking awkward questions? Definitely. Does that mean making mistakes? Sure.
I write characters that aren't white, because I write people. I don't pretend to KNOW EVERYTHING. I just try for honest representation.
It could be worse. At least you have goals. ;)
So yeah, that's my philosophy on life: Be nice and learn from others. You have no idea what they have survived to still be here.
That's why I try so damned hard to be accepting and open to people. I want to learn, to feel, to understand. I don't want to cause pain.
Does that mean I understand what it is like to be a POC? Hell no. But I can understand what it feels like to be discriminated against.
My understanding of prejudice is colored by my experiences as a #bisexual man. Some people treat me like I'm diseased, untouchable.
It's not impossible to understand something you haven't experienced. It just takes more work. Correlation.
I mean, how many people make it a goal to feed needy children everyday? Those people were probably hungry at some point. Really hungry.
We understand that there are starving children, we have been told repeatedly, but how many of us actually go out and do something about it?
To effectively change, people have to feel and they have to understand. Both together. Just one won't make it stick for most people.
Instead of just shocking people, hoping they'll change. People don't change easily. It is possible, but don't expect it.
The difference now is that I CHOOSE to make the world a better place. I fight for the things I think are important.
TBH, that never really went away. I still think that humans are painfully myopic as a species. We are little monsters who create death.
I got cold. I ripped people's precious security blankets away. I made people uncomfortable because I felt they needed it.
It wasn't just racism and prejudice, it was realizing what the real world was like. I spent most of my young adulthood hating everything.
When I realized what life was like for people I cared about and extrapolated that to the rest of the world... Well, something broke in me.
None of them were surprised. I had been white and male enough that I had only been knocked down and beaten up a couple times a year.
I left high school a year early. I was getting harassed and attacked regularly. Complaining to my friends, they confided that it was common.
I was a nerd who loved anime, manga, gaming, and comic books. High school was difficult before I came out as bisexual.
What changed? 1. I saw how my friends were treated. 2. I studied history. 3. I was discriminated against.
Now, I was a 'good person'. I didn't call people racial epitaphs. I never consciously discriminated, but I was ignorant as fuck.
There was a time when I thought "I have minority friends, I'm not racist." was a valid argument. (it's not.)
But still, I harbored prejudices that were taught to me by society. From being uncomfortable around people for no good reason, to judging.
Admitting fault and changing beliefs are hard for people who have ingrained these beliefs. I'm lucky, I grew up loving everyone I met.
First of all, you have to realize that your understanding will be imperfect. You have to realize that you are likely wrong about things.
And by it, I mean subtle prejudice. I was guilty of thinking I couldn't be racist, because I didn't want to be.

So, I'm not saying micro-manage every second of your time. Just be mindful of your body. I create better when I feel better.
Diabetes forces me to adhere to some sort of schedule, and I write better when I am actively managing my meds, but I so hate that I have to.
It sounds simple, and it is. When you are working on something for a long time, effectively in seclusion, it can be easy to forget.
Seriously though, listen to your body, drink water, and take breaks. Your brain will thank you for it and you'll write better.
Preventing pain has multiple benefits: preventing long-term damage and increased productivity. Also, I'm less likely to whine.

the injection was fine, I take 2 types of insulin: short-term and long-term. One is for meals(short-term) one is all day.
Everyone tries to give you peanut butter on bread. Or orange juice. Take the orange juice. Sip it, don't gulp. #diabetes
People will want to give you protein to 'stabilize' you. Don't listen. You'll get sick, losing all those precious carbohydrates.
If you ever misinject insulin, my recommendation is not to eat, but to drink. You body processes the carbs faster, less likely to vomit.
1. Ingest carbs(liquid easiest) 2. Test blood sugar every 15 minutes. 3. Don't be alone. (In case of seizures, unconsciousness, death.)
So, I'm drinking a Gatoraid and trying not to vomit. The joys of being diabetic and stupid. The bright side: I know what to do to be safe.

Hug your family, hug your friends. Love. I've got nothing left to say. If we let this continue, it's on us.
I've been having a hard time finding words since Pulse, because that's MY PEOPLE. It will never stop though, unless we stop it.
Because the alternative is watching innocent people die. Or worse, pretending it isn't happening. I refuse to do that. You should too.
That's all it will take, we just have to keep fighting, keep believing. Look at how far we have come, we  can do it. We have to.
So, if you cannot fight one way, fight another. Breathe compassion, love, and acceptance into the world. Be an example, be a hero.
We love heroes who embody the best of us. We want to be Superman, not because he's strong, but because he's good DESPITE being strong.
Why do we, nerds, like Captain America and (good) Superman stories? Not because they are super strong and neigh-invulnerable.
Tolkien says, pretty unequivocally, that the fight is WORTH IT. That people are worth it, we just have to believe. We just have to fight.
Tolkien was talking about the peoples of Britain, most likely, but the story stands because it is a story of triumph through sacrifice.
Lord of the Rings is a great example. It literally has a underappreciated (and often mocked) group of people for it's protagonists.
If you are an artist, draw to fight oppression! If you are a writer, write to fight oppression! If you programmer, code to fight oppression!
We can still fight. I know, not everyone is made for political debate. I have bipolar, anxiety, and Type 1 diabetes; I understand limits.
But, You have to survive, pay bills, raise children, try not to go crazy. There's no time to save the world.
The stories I've heard from friends my whole life, how could you hear that stuff and not be angry? How many people have to be shoved down?
The sort of shit my mother survived. In the 60's, attempted rapists would get driven to the county line. After kidnapping multiple people.
Through all of this: I'm still luckier than a PoC or a woman. They are constantly unappreciated, underpaid, and the recipients of bigotry.
I've been told people like me are sick, should be sterilized, shouldn't be allowed to raise children. I've been attacked for being bisexual.
I left high school my junior year. I went to night school and summer school to get out early. Harassment was a huge reason why.
I came out in high school when a 'friend' of mine told me that all gay people should be killed. By the end of the day, the whole school knew
I argued social tolerance, freedom of expression, and honesty in government, at 12. By the time I was 18, I had been beaten down by reality.
The realization of how horrible humans were, daily, destroyed a part of my innocence forever. I spent years screaming, 'It's unfair!'
I learned about prejudice by living in the world. Again, when I had questions, my mother sat me down and explained the way of the world.
This didn't mean I didn't make mistakes. I grew up in a state that has 89% white people. I was painfully ignorant of other cultures.
I saw my parents treat PoC and LGBTQIA people as people. So I treated them as people. Compassion is taught, just like hate.
I was lucky to be raised by a parents who actively talked against bigotry and hatred, I inherited a culture of compassion.
And Yes, I'm a stupid, lucky privileged white person. I'm not the person taking the hardest burden. But I was taught all people are PEOPLE.
This isn't a just Black problem, or a LGBTQIA problem, or a poor problem. Though they take the burden of our inaction.
We let mass shootings continue with out legislation, we let police kill citizens and we aren't fighting to stop it, we are complacent.
Make no mistake WE are killing people with our complacency.
When we kill people, we destroy their potential forever. We mutilate the lives of their surviving family and friends. It creates ripples.
No, it's not happening anywhere near fast enough. We waste our potential as a species by not HELPING each other.
History shows us that we CAN create societies that take care of their people and try to help the world, but to do that we have to engage.
The problem is we believe we cannot effect change. As a group, we need to eradicate this idea. If you don't believe me study history.
Your music made me think, made me feel, and it made me want to move. It doesn't get better than that! So, Thank you!
My brother's words made me realize: there are people fighting to make the world a better place all the time, in their own ways.
I've always been so damned unhappy about the unfairness of the world, the horrible nature of humans, and our inability to help one another.
He doesn't deny it, he doesn't pretend that life doesn't have problems, he just CHOOSES to find happiness ANYWAY. This kinda broke my brain.
I asked my brother recently how he "Deals with the horrible things he knows are coming", like death. He said, "I choose positivity."
Don't get me wrong, I understand enough to know why it's not easy. I just don't agree with the notion it cannot be changed in our time.
I mostly talk books, games, and comics, but the world is messed up and we need to stop killing each other! It shouldn't be this hard!

To clarify: Candida yeast exists. Usually not a problem. Cure diets, pills, special acidophilus to cure you: Those are all bullshit.
Yes, you are correct and I should be more clear.
I had thrush. It was before I was diagnosed with Type 1 Diabetes. I was very ill, my body couldn't fight off the fungus. It was easily cured
Now, vaginal yeast infections and thrush are obviously real things, but they are a symptom of another problem: A compromised immune system.

I draw comic art, primarily emulating Japanese Manga, among other influences. So yeah- photo-realism  was never a goal.
So, I have some catch up to do. It is worth the investment for the future, considering how many stories I want to write.
I've only mastered the techniques I wanted to master. That's my problem with editing, I never thought I'd have to master it.
I am not a 'great artist'. I learned to draw what I wanted to draw and got bored. I like telling stories more.
I'm not putting down practice, when people tell me they wish 'they could draw', I say they can if they practice.
While there are standards of what is beautiful or attractive, these things are subjective and based on psychology and culture.
Studying physiology, proportion, and perspective is important, but psychology is important also. Aesthetics are instinctual responses.
It compares to drawing, you only get better with research and practice. Both are equally important.
Editing is something that does not come naturally for me. It is a product of practice and perseverance. I still have a lot to learn.
I'm thinking of creating a grammar cheat sheet so I don't forget things while I'm editing. It will be worth it for the future.

Most minorities don't have that luxury, they can't hide physical differences, they can't be invisible to bigots. Think about that.
Here's the thing that REALLY drove it home: Nobody can look at me and see my sexuality. I 'pass' to the average bigoted asshat.
The only reason I have an inkling is because I have amazing parents and a life-time of being descriminated against because of my sexuality.
This is what most white people, esp. men, don't get. Until you see it or experience it, it's hard to understand how pervasive it really is.
Despite the fact there are scars on my body from prejudice, I don't really think I understand what it's like to be female or a minority.
I'm bisexual. I've lost friends because of it, people have physically attacked me, I've been spit on, insulted, and berated.
Why am I talking about this at all? Because I have to remind myself that I can just ignore it and it won't affect my life. This is privilege
The fact that this happens so rarely is white privledge. Minorities have to deal with that crap constantly, in much more pervasive ways.
So I always get frusfrated when I see 'white people are...' articles, because I hate being lumped in with the assholes, bigots, and racists.

Making myself feel better over the loss of my monitor by playing FFVII. I conspired with my son's mother to steal my PSone back from him.

Not feeling sick: Fucking Priceless! First day in over two weeks where I didn't feel like dried mung. Happiness.

Today ranks right up there with 'the boring day' but, still not depressed. Just feel like crap. (Diabetics are really zombies! Pass it on!)
